isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - 13 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS EATON RT-6613 SERIES - AIR SYSTEM - SELECTOR VALVE

svcsubproc.title: Description
svcsubproc.para: Porting - There are four ports in the bottom of the selector valve:

item.para: The port stamped "S" is the supply port and is the constant air line from the air valve.
The port stamped "E" is the exhaust port and is left open.
The port stamped "R" is the signal line to the slave air valve.
The port stamped "F" is the signal line to the intermediate shift cylinder.

svcsubproc.title: Troubleshooting

step1.para: With the selector valve button in "LO" position, disconnect the two lines connected to the port "R" and "F." There should be no air coming out of these ports.
Move the selector valve button to "INT." There should now be a steady flow of air coming from the "F" port, but still no air coming from the "R" port.
Move the selector valve button to the "DIR" position. There should now be a steady flow of air coming from both the "F" and "R" ports.
Maintenance and Assembly - The selector valve is easily disassembled by removing the cover screws. Individual parts can be obtained in an "A" number kit. Critical assembly factors are:

step2.para: Make sure the jam nut locking the selector valve to the shifting lever is secure.
Make sure that when reassembled, the top plate screws are tightened securely. A loose top plate screw can affect valve operation.
When reassembling, lubricate the O-ring and O-ring carrier with a silicone lubricant.

svcsubproc.para: If the above results are not obtained, disconnect the supply air line at the "S" port and make sure that a steady flow of air is coming through the line. If air is present, this would indicate a faulty selector valve. Cause can be defective parts, damaged O-ring or loose top plate screw.

step1.para: Any steady flow of air from the selector valve exhaust port indicates a faulty selector valve or incorrect hook-up. Cause can be damaged O-ring, defective parts, loose top plate screw or reversed air lines on the selector.
